column2: PART TWELVE
column3: PART TWELVE

column2: It was when I read the first of the books I found in my house that I saw the word "I." And when I understood this word, the book fell from my hands, and I wept, I who had never known tears.
column3: It was when I read the first of the books I found in my house that I saw the word "I." And when I understood this word, the book fell from my hands, and I wept, I who had never known tears.

column2: I wept in deliverance and in pity for all mankind.
column3: I wept in deliverance and in pity for all mankind.

column2: I understood the blessed thing which I had called my curse.
column3: I understood the blessed thing which I had called my curse.

column2: I understood why the best in me had been my sins and my transgressions; and why I had never felt guilt in my sins.
column3: I understood why the best in me had been my sins and my transgressions; and why I had never felt guilt in my sins.

column2: I understood that centuries of chains and lashes will not kill the spirit of man nor the sense of truth within him.
column3: I understood that centuries of chains and lashes will not kill the spirit of man nor the sense of truth within him.

column2: I read many books for many days.
column3: I read many books for many days.

column2: Then I called the Golden One, and I told her what I had read and what I had learned.
column3: Then I called the Golden One, and I told her what I had read and what I had learned.

column2: She looked at me and the first words she spoke were:
column3: She looked at me and the first words she spoke were:

column2: I love you.
column3: I love you.

column2: Then I said:
column3: Then I said:

column2: My dearest one, it is not proper for men to be without names.	My dearest one, it is not proper for men to be without names.
column3: true

column2: There was a time when each man had a name of his own to distinguish him from all other men.
column3: There was a time when each man had a name of his own to distinguish him from all other men.

column2: So let us choose our names.
column3: So let us choose our names.

column2: I have read of a man who lived many thousands of years ago, and of all the names in these books, his is the one I wish to bear.
column3: I have read of a man who lived many thousands of years ago, and of all the names in these books, his is the one I wish to bear.

column2: He took the light of the gods and he brought it to men, and he taught men to be gods.
column3: He took the light of the gods and he brought it to men, and he taught men to be gods.

column2: And he suffered for his deed as all bearers of light must suffer.
column3: And he suffered for his deed as all bearers of light must suffer.

column2: His name was Prometheus."
column3: His name was Prometheus."

column2: It shall be your name, said the Golden One.
column3: It shall be your name, said the Golden One.

column2: And I have read of a goddess, I said, "who was the mother of the earth and of all the gods.
column3: And I have read of a goddess, I said, "who was the mother of the earth and of all the gods.

column2: Her name was Gaea.
column3: Her name was Gaea.

column2: Let this be your name, my Golden One, for you are to be the mother of a new kind of gods."
column3: Let this be your name, my Golden One, for you are to be the mother of a new kind of gods."

column2: It shall be my name, said the Golden One.
column3: It shall be my name, said the Golden One.

column2: Now I look ahead.
column3: Now I look ahead.

column2: My future is clear before me.
column3: My future is clear before me.

column2: The Saint of the pyre had seen the future when he chose me as his heir, as the heir of all the saints and all the martyrs who came before him and who died for the same cause, for the same word, no matter what name they gave to their cause and their truth.
column3: The Saint of the pyre had seen the future when he chose me as his heir, as the heir of all the saints and all the martyrs who came before him and who died for the same cause, for the same word, no matter what name they gave to their cause and their truth.

column2: I shall live here, in my own house.
column3: I shall live here, in my own house.

column2: I shall take my food from the earth by the toil of my own hands.
column3: I shall take my food from the earth by the toil of my own hands.

column2: I shall learn many secrets from my books. Through the years ahead, I shall rebuild the achievements of the past, and open the way to carry them further, the achievements which are open to me, but closed forever to my brothers, for their minds are shackled to the weakest and dullest ones among them.
column3: I shall learn many secrets from my books. Through the years ahead, I shall rebuild the achievements of the past, and open the way to carry them further, the achievements which are open to me, but closed forever to my brothers, for their minds are shackled to the weakest and dullest ones among them.

column2: I have learned that my power of the sky was known to men long ago; they called it Electricity.
column3: I have learned that my power of the sky was known to men long ago; they called it Electricity.

column2: It was the power that moved their greatest inventions.
column3: It was the power that moved their greatest inventions.

column2: It lit this house with light which came from those globes of glass on the walls.
column3: It lit this house with light which came from those globes of glass on the walls.

column2: I have found the engine which produced this light. I shall learn how to repair it and how to make it work again.
column3: I have found the engine which produced this light. I shall learn how to repair it and how to make it work again.

column2: I shall learn how to use the wires which carry this power.
column3: I shall learn how to use the wires which carry this power.

column2: Then I shall build a barrier of wires around my home, and across the paths which lead to my home; a barrier light as a cobweb, more impassable than a wall of granite; a barrier my brothers will never be able to cross.
column3: Then I shall build a barrier of wires around my home, and across the paths which lead to my home; a barrier light as a cobweb, more impassable than a wall of granite; a barrier my brothers will never be able to cross.

column2: For they have nothing to fight me with, save the brute force of their numbers.
column3: For they have nothing to fight me with, save the brute force of their numbers.

column2: I have my mind.
column3: I have my mind.

column2: Then here, on this mountaintop, with the world below me and nothing above me but the sun, I shall live my own truth.
column3: Then here, on this mountaintop, with the world below me and nothing above me but the sun, I shall live my own truth.

column2: Gaea is pregnant with my child.
column3: Gaea is pregnant with my child.

column2: Our son will be raised as a man.
column3: Our son will be raised as a man.

column2: He will be taught to say "I" and to bear the pride of it.
column3: He will be taught to say "I" and to bear the pride of it.

column2: He will be taught to walk straight and on his own feet.
column3: He will be taught to walk straight and on his own feet.

column2: He will be taught reverence for his own spirit.
column3: He will be taught reverence for his own spirit.

column2: When I shall have read all the books and learned my new way, when my home will be ready and my earth tilled, I shall steal one day, for the last time, into the cursed City of my birth.
column3: When I shall have read all the books and learned my new way, when my home will be ready and my earth tilled, I shall steal one day, for the last time, into the cursed City of my birth.

column2: I shall call to me my friend who has no name save International 4-8818, and all those like him, Fraternity 2-5503, who cries without reason, and Solidarity 9-6347 who calls for help in the night, and a few others.
column3: I shall call to me my friend who has no name save International four minus eight thousand eight hundred eighteen, and all those like him, Fraternity two minus five thousand five hundred three, who cries without reason, and Solidarity nine minus six thousand three hundred forty seven who calls for help in the night, and a few others.

column2: I shall call to me all the men and the women whose spirit has not been killed within them and who suffer under the yoke of their brothers.
column3: I shall call to me all the men and the women whose spirit has not been killed within them and who suffer under the yoke of their brothers.

column2: They will follow me and I shall lead them to my fortress.
column3: They will follow me and I shall lead them to my fortress.

column2: And here, in this uncharted wilderness, I and they, my chosen friends, my fellow-builders, shall write the first chapter in the new history of man.
column3: And here, in this uncharted wilderness, I and they, my chosen friends, my fellow builders, shall write the first chapter in the new history of man.

column2: These are the things before me.
column3: These are the things before me.

column2: And as I stand here at the door of glory, I look behind me for the last time.
column3: And as I stand here at the door of glory, I look behind me for the last time.

column2: I look upon the history of men, which I have learned from the books, and I wonder.
column3: I look upon the history of men, which I have learned from the books, and I wonder.

column2: It was a long story, and the spirit which moved it was the spirit of man's freedom. But what is freedom?
column3: It was a long story, and the spirit which moved it was the spirit of man's freedom. But what is freedom?

column2: Freedom from what?
column3: Freedom from what?

column2: There is nothing to take a man's freedom away from him, save other men.
column3: There is nothing to take a man's freedom away from him, save other men.

column2: To be free, a man must be free of his brothers.
column3: To be free, a man must be free of his brothers.

column2: That is freedom.
column3: That is freedom.

column2: That and nothing else.
column3: That and nothing else.

column2: At first, man was enslaved by the gods.
column3: At first, man was enslaved by the gods.

column2: But he broke their chains.
column3: But he broke their chains.

column2: Then he was enslaved by the kings.
column3: Then he was enslaved by the kings.

column2: But he broke their chains.
column3: But he broke their chains.

column2: He was enslaved by his birth, by his kin, by his race.
column3: He was enslaved by his birth, by his kin, by his race.

column2: But he broke their chains.
column3: But he broke their chains.

column2: He declared to all his brothers that a man has rights which neither god nor king nor other men can take away from him, no matter what their number, for his is the right of man, and there is no right on earth above this right.
column3: He declared to all his brothers that a man has rights which neither god nor king nor other men can take away from him, no matter what their number, for his is the right of man, and there is no right on earth above this right.

column2: And he stood on the threshold of the freedom for which the blood of the centuries behind him had been spilled.
column3: And he stood on the threshold of the freedom for which the blood of the centuries behind him had been spilled.

column2: But then he gave up all he had won, and fell lower than his savage beginning.
column3: But then he gave up all he had won, and fell lower than his savage beginning.

column2: What brought it to pass?
column3: What brought it to pass?

column2: What disaster took their reason away from men?
column3: What disaster took their reason away from men?

column2: What whip lashed them to their knees in shame and submission?
column3: What whip lashed them to their knees in shame and submission?

column2: The worship of the word "We."
column3: The worship of the word "We."

column2: When men accepted that worship, the structure of centuries collapsed about them, the structure whose every beam had come from the thought of some one man, each in his day down the ages, from the depth of some one spirit, such spirit as existed but for its own sake.
column3: When men accepted that worship, the structure of centuries collapsed about them, the structure whose every beam had come from the thought of some one man, each in his day down the ages, from the depth of some one spirit, such spirit as existed but for its own sake.

column2: Those men who survived those eager to obey, eager to live for one another, since they had nothing else to vindicate them--those men could neither carry on, nor preserve what they had received.
column3: Those men who survived those eager to obey, eager to live for one another, since they had nothing else to vindicate them-those men could neither carry on, nor preserve what they had received.

column2: Thus did all thought, all science, all wisdom perish on earth.
column3: Thus did all thought, all science, all wisdom perish on earth.

column2: Thus did men--men with nothing to offer save their great number--lost the steel towers, the flying ships, the power wires, all the things they had not created and could never keep. Perhaps, later, some men had been born with the mind and the courage to recover these things which were lost; perhaps these men came before the Councils of Scholars.
column3: Thus did men-men with nothing to offer save their great number-lost the steel towers, the flying ships, the power wires, all the things they had not created and could never keep. Perhaps, later, some men had been born with the mind and the courage to recover these things which were lost; perhaps these men came before the Councils of Scholars.

column2: They were answered as I have been answered--and for the same reasons.
column3: They were answered as I have been answered-and for the same reasons.

column2: But I still wonder how it was possible, in those graceless years of transition, long ago, that men did not see whither they were going, and went on, in blindness and cowardice, to their fate.
column3: But I still wonder how it was possible, in those graceless years of transition, long ago, that men did not see whither they were going, and went on, in blindness and cowardice, to their fate.

column2: I wonder, for it is hard for me to conceive how men who knew the word "I" could give it up and not know what they lost.
column3: I wonder, for it is hard for me to conceive how men who knew the word "I" could give it up and not know what they lost.

column2: But such has been the story, for I have lived in the City of the damned, and I know what horror men permitted to be brought upon them.
column3: But such has been the story, for I have lived in the City of the damned, and I know what horror men permitted to be brought upon them.

column2: Perhaps, in those days, there were a few among men, a few of clear sight and clean soul, who refused to surrender that word.
column3: Perhaps, in those days, there were a few among men, a few of clear sight and clean soul, who refused to surrender that word.

column2: What agony must have been theirs before that which they saw coming and could not stop! Perhaps they cried out in protest and in warning.
column3: What agony must have been theirs before that which they saw coming and could not stop! Perhaps they cried out in protest and in warning.

column2: But men paid no heed to their warning.
column3: But men paid no heed to their warning.

column2: And they, these few, fought a hopeless battle, and they perished with their banners smeared by their own blood.
column3: And they, these few, fought a hopeless battle, and they perished with their banners smeared by their own blood.

column2: And they chose to perish, for they knew.
column3: And they chose to perish, for they knew.

column2: To them, I send my salute across the centuries, and my pity.
column3: To them, I send my salute across the centuries, and my pity.

column2: Theirs is the banner in my hand.
column3: Theirs is the banner in my hand.

column2: And I wish I had the power to tell them that the despair of their hearts was not to be final, and their night was not without hope.
column3: And I wish I had the power to tell them that the despair of their hearts was not to be final, and their night was not without hope.

column2: For the battle they lost can never be lost.
column3: For the battle they lost can never be lost.

column2: For that which they died to save can never perish.
column3: For that which they died to save can never perish.

column2: Through all the darkness, through all the shame of which men are capable, the spirit of man will remain alive on this earth.
column3: Through all the darkness, through all the shame of which men are capable, the spirit of man will remain alive on this earth.

column2: It may sleep, but it will awaken.
column3: It may sleep, but it will awaken.

column2: It may wear chains, but it will break through.
column3: It may wear chains, but it will break through.

column2: And man will go on.
column3: And man will go on.

column2: Man, not men.
column3: Man, not men.

column2: Here on this mountain, I and my sons and my chosen friends shall build our new land and our fort.
column3: Here on this mountain, I and my sons and my chosen friends shall build our new land and our fort.

column2: And it will become as the heart of the earth, lost and hidden at first, but beating, beating louder each day.
column3: And it will become as the heart of the earth, lost and hidden at first, but beating, beating louder each day.

column2: And word of it will reach every corner of the earth.
column3: And word of it will reach every corner of the earth.

column2: And the roads of the world will become as veins which will carry the best of the world's blood to my threshold.
column3: And the roads of the world will become as veins which will carry the best of the world's blood to my threshold.

column2: And all my brothers, and the Councils of my brothers, will hear of it, but they will be impotent against me.
column3: And all my brothers, and the Councils of my brothers, will hear of it, but they will be impotent against me.

column2: And the day will come when I shall break all the chains of the earth, and raze the cities of the enslaved, and my home will become the capital of a world where each man will be free to exist for his own sake.
column3: And the day will come when I shall break all the chains of the earth, and raze the cities of the enslaved, and my home will become the capital of a world where each man will be free to exist for his own sake.

column2: For the coming of that day shall I fight, I and my sons and my chosen friends.
column3: For the coming of that day shall I fight, I and my sons and my chosen friends.

column2: For the freedom of Man.
column3: For the freedom of Man.

column2: For his rights.
column3: For his rights.

column2: For his life.
column3: For his life.

column2: For his honor.
column3: For his honor.

column2: And here, over the portals of my fort, I shall cut in the stone the word which is to be my beacon and my banner.
column3: And here, over the portals of my fort, I shall cut in the stone the word which is to be my beacon and my banner.

column2: The word which will not die, should we all perish in battle.
column3: The word which will not die, should we all perish in battle.

column2: The word which can never die on this earth, for it is the heart of it and the meaning and the glory.
column3: The word which can never die on this earth, for it is the heart of it and the meaning and the glory.

column2: The sacred word:
column3: The sacred word:

column2: EGO
column3: EGO
